title: A protocol for detecting elemental calcium signals (Ca2+ puffs) in mammalian cells using total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparing cells for imaging
Timing: 2 days
Coating coverslips with poly-D-lysine Coating the coverslips promotes cell adhesion and ensures that the cells are intact (not washed off) during the subsequent washing steps with imaging buffer.
Pre-warm cell culture media, DPBS, trypsin, poly-D-lysine (0.1 mg/mL) by placing in a water bath set to 37°C.
Using tweezers gently place pre-autoclaved 15 mm No1 coverslips in each well of a 12-well cell culture plate.
Coat the coverslips by adding 0.1–0.2 mL poly-D-lysine/well of the 12-well plate to sufficiently cover the coverslips in each well.
Incubate for 1 h at room temperature (25°C) in the laminar flow cabinet.
Remove poly-D-lysine and rinse the wells 3 times with DPBS.
Leave the plates uncovered for at least 1 h in the laminar flow cabinet for drying.
Seeding cells for imaging
Seed 0.5 × 106 cells in each well of a 12-well plate with poly-D-lysine coated coverslip (prepared in the previous step) in 1 mL cell culture media.
Leave the plates in an incubator for 48 h.
Detecting calcium signals using TIRF microscopy
Timing: 5 h
Loading cells with Cal-520-AM (Ca2+ indicator), ci-IP3-PM (cell permeable caged IP3 analog), and EGTA-AM (cell permeable Ca2+ chelator).
After 48 h, view the cells under a microscope using brightfield illumination and ensure that the cells have adhered and attained flattened morphology.
Prepare 5 μM Cal-520-AM and 1 μM ci-IP3-PM by dissolving 5μL 1 mM Cal-520-AM and 1 μL 1 mM ci-IP3-PM in 1 mL imaging buffer supplemented with 1% BSA.
Prepare 5 μM EGTA-AM by dissolving 5 μL 10 mM EGTA in 10 mL imaging buffer.
Using fine-tip forceps, transfer the cells on coverslip from step (a) into a 35-mm dish in the laminar flow cabinet.

Wash the coverslip gently three times with 750 μL imaging buffer.
Discard the imaging buffer and incubate the coverslip in 750 μL Cal-520-AM and ci-IP3-PM supplemented imaging buffer (prepared in step b).
Incubate at 25°C for an hour. Following 1 h incubation, rinse the coverslip gently with imaging buffer three times.
Discard the imaging buffer and gently add 750 μL of EGTA-AM supplemented imaging buffer (prepared in step c).
Incubate at 25°C for 45 min. Following 45 min incubation, rinse the coverslip gently with imaging buffer three times.
Discard the imaging buffer. Add 750 μL fresh imaging buffer and incubate at 25°C for another 45 min to facilitate complete de-esterification of the loaded reagents.
Critical: All the incubations steps are at room temperature (25°C) to avoid indicator sequestration into organelles and in the dark to prevent photo-degradation of the loaded indicator. Do not freeze/re-use the diluted Cal-520-AM/ci-IP3-PM mixture.
Imaging Ca2+ puffs using TIRF microscopy
Using fine forceps, attach the coverslip to a Warner perfusion chamber using vacuum grease. For each experimental set, image at least 5 coverslips.
Add 1 mL imaging buffer to the perfusion chamber to ensure that the cells are properly immersed.
Clean the bottom of the cover slip using a kimwipe to avoid artifacts while focusing/imaging.
On an Olympus IX81 inverted microscope equipped with PlanApo 60x/1.45 Oil TIRFM Microscope Objective, place a drop of low autofluorescence immersion oil.
Next, fasten the Warner perfusion chamber on to the microscope stage.
We use Olympus CellSens Dimensions 2.3 (Build 189987) software for imaging (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Figure 3. Parameters that can be adjusted in the cellSens Dimension imaging software to acquire Ca2+ puffs
(A) Camera control window allows acquiring movies/snapshots, adjusting the exposure time (gain), resolution, and field of view/region of interest for recording Ca2+ puffs.
(B) The laser/LED control tab permits selection of appropriate laser and laser intensity to illuminate the dye loaded cells.
(C) Adjust display facilitates optimizing the appearance of dye loaded cells.
(D) Experiment manager window enables creating, saving, and executing a protocol for image acquisition. In this window, a series of commands including the laser type, exposure time, controlling UV laser shutters, and recording time for running an experiment can be defined.
(E) A protocol used for acquiring a three second baseline (prior to photolysis), delivering UV flash from a 405 nm laser for 1 s (photolysis of ci-IP3), followed by recording Ca2+ puffs for 40 s using the 488 nm laser is presented.
(F) The angle of incidence of laser to achieve total internal reflection can be optimized by adjusting the angle offset in the TIRF adjustment window. The penetration depth which varies with incident angle and other fixed parameters such as refractive indexes of glass, sample, numerical aperture, critical angle, maximal angle is displayed in this tab.
Excite Cal-520 indicator using a 488 nm laser (set the intensity to a minimum such that the indicator fluorescence does not photobleach; see solution in “problems 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.3] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.5]”); ensure that the cells are in focus and in the incident angle of the laser achieves TIRF (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2], 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A, 3C, and 3E). Fluorescence in TIRF mode characteristically reveals the interface between the plasma membrane and the coverslip (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A). See solution in “problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.1]” if this does not occur.

Figure 4. TIRF imaging using hR1 endo cells

(A) A hR1 endo cell illustrating the sites at which puffs were observed upon uncaging ci-IP3. Scale bar: 10 μm.
(B) Traces showing the changes in fluorescence from the depicted regions of interest (1 μm by 1 μm) in A.
(C) Time course of a Ca2+ puff is shown on an expanded time scale.
(D) Gaussian blurred images of a representative Ca2+ puff over the entire duration of the puff obtained from a region of a cell. Scale bar: 2 μm.
Set the protocol in the software to record baseline (during which the cells are quiescent) for at least 3/5 s; deliver a UV-flash using a 405 nm laser uniformly to uncage ci-IP3 for 1 s (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B and 3D; see solution in “problems 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.7] and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.9]”). Alternatively, the UV laser light may be focused to a spot to illuminate a region of a cell.
Following uncaging, record the Ca2+ puffs for a user-defined time period (for example 1 min or until the calcium signals globalize).
Capture the emitted fluorescence using a Hamamatsu ORCA-fusion CMOS digital camera C14440. Images were acquired from a final field of (86.7 × 86.7 μm) 400 × 400 pixels (one pixel=216 nm), penetration depth of ∼140 nm at a rate of ∼97 frames/s (binning 2 × 2), and at an exposure of 10 msec (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Critical: All the necessary precautions must be considered before operating the lasers. Lasers can cause irreparable damage to the eye and skin burns. Although the Olympus TIRF condenser employs a laser interrupt when laser light is directed to the eyepieces it is recommended that appropriate goggles to protect eyes and long-sleeve gloves to protect skin from laser burns are worn.

Critical: Ensure that the lights are off during the entire process of imaging. Set the 488 nm laser intensity to a minimum to avoid photobleaching/spontaneous puff activity. The optimum laser intensity for imaging can be confirmed by using HEK-293 cells which lack all the 3 endogenous IP3Rs (HEK-3KO). It is also critical to optimize the intensity of the UV flash (typically in the range of 0.1–2 mW) and duration (100 ms–1000 ms) for uncaging ci-IP3-PM. The speed of recording can be enhanced by increasing the binning to 4 × 4. Following dye loading, cells appear healthy and can be used for acquiring images for at least ∼45 min. Each coverslip can be used to acquire multiple recordings since the focused UV-laser used to uncage ci-IP3 triggers uncaging in the field of view and only a small fraction of cells on the coverslips are exposed to laser light. Nevertheless, avoid recording puffs from the same field of view more than once.
Alternatives: Cells can also be superfused with a Gαq-coupled agonist using a perfusion system to elevate intracellular levels of IP3 to evoke Ca2+ puffs (Emrich et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Lock et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). Cal-590-AM indicator can be used in place of Cal-520-AM which differ in their excitation/emission wavelengths (558/584 nm and 492/514 nm for Cal-590 and Cal-520, respectively) and also their affinities for Ca2+ (kd=561 nM and 320 nM for Cal-590 and Cal-520, respectively). The long excitation/emission wavelength of Cal-590 makes it compatible for use with multicolor detection, for example, with GFP tagged proteins (Thillaiappan et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).

Analyzing Ca2+ puffs using FLIKA software
Timing: 3 h
Convert the .vsi files obtained using CellSens Dimensions 2.3 software into .tif format using Image J (Fiji). Further analysis to determine various spatio-temporal and biophysical parameters such as number of puffs/cell, number of puff sites/cell, rise and fall times are obtained using FLIKA software developed by Dr. Ian Parker’s group (Ellefsen et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Ellefsen et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]). The steps involved in analyzing Ca2+ puffs using FLIKA software are outlined below:
Load .tif file (Crop to accommodate a single cell, trim frames to be analyzed).
On graphical user interface, select Process – Math – Subtract (for example 450, black levels).
Select the Subtracted window - Process – Math – Ratio by Baseline [First frame – 0, Number of frames – 290 (before uncaging ci-IP3), Ratio Type – Average, Black Level – 0.00] – Data window containing F/Fo (A) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Select the Ratioed by Average window – Process – filter – Butterworth filter – Filter order 3 – Low cutoff Frequency (e.g.: 2) High cutoff Frequency (e.g.: 10), Frame rate (Hz) (e.g.: 97 fps).
Select the Ratioed by Average – Butter Filtered window – Process – Math – Ratio by Baseline [First frame – 0, Number of frames – 290 (before uncaging ci-IP3), Ratio Type – standard deviation, Black Level – 0.00] – Normalized window containing data with baseline at 0 (B).

Select the Ratioed by average – butter filtered – Ratioed by standard deviation window –Process – Filter – Gaussian Blur – Sigma (pixels) (e.g.: 3), normalized edges, preview (true); adjust the histogram in a manner to detect puffs (e.g.: 1). – Gaussian Blurred normalized window (C) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Plugins – Detect Puffs – Threshold cluster – select the appropriate windows (A, B, C). Enter the values pertaining to Roi_width (e.g.: 5), paddingXY (e.g.: 20), padding_pre (e.g.: 20), padding_post (e.g.: 20), maxSigma For GaussianFit (e.g.: 90), radius (e.g.: 5), maxPuffDiameter (e.g.: 30), blur_thresh (e.g.: 1), time_factor (e.g.: 2). Load_flika_file (false). Rotatedfit (true).
Blur Threshold (enter the desired value (e.g.: 1.00). Hit set threshold.
Right click and circle the clusters.
Hit set threshold.
Fit Gaussian.
In control panel, monitor the individual puffs adjust start and end of individual puff.
Export to excel which has details about events assigned to clusters (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C), the amplitudes (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A), number of puff sites/number of puffs (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B), rise and fall times (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C).

Note: The parameters mentioned in parenthesis as examples work best for hR1 endo cells and with our microscope settings, however, these parameters vary based on the cell types/speed of recording/number of puffs/frequency of puffs/duration of puff/radius of puffs and other factors. Hence, they need to be optimized accordingly. All the puffs identified automatically by the algorithm were manually confirmed before analysis. For a detailed guide on all the parameters for detect puff plugin, please refer to the help section in FLIKAGUI (https://github.com/kyleellefsen/detect_puffs/blob/master/docs/detect_puffs_parameters.md[href=https://github.com/kyleellefsen/detect_puffs/blob/master/docs/detect_puffs_parameters.md]) (Ellefsen et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
